 Let's forget the 'fear' thing, I suppose (just an unnecessary jab).
 
 Most religions are built on the same philosophical assumptions that under-gird science, i.e. that there are objective 'things' outside of our experience, and that these objective things can be observed, tested, manipulated, etc, without alteration.
 
 The Christian Science worldview starts from much more subjectivist foundations, believing that all is essentially Mind (i.e. G-d and his creation), and taking quite literally the belief that G-d created man in his image and likeness, as it says in the first chapter of Genesis in the Bible.
 
 In Christian Science, we start from a priori assumptions about man, based on the description of man and his relation to G-d, as stated in the Bible. If those starting assumptions are true, then the deductions made in Christian Science are also.
 
 Sickness, and sin ('sin' meaning literally 'to be apart from G-d,' as in the Biblical Greek), then, stem from our misapprehension of our relationship with G-d, rather than from physical causation. A Christian Science treatment, then, involves the relinquishment of our false concepts about ourselves and our origins. In bringing our consciousness into alignment with the divine (and in 'forgetting' the seeming conditions presented us by a material world), Christian Scientists are often able to treat sickness / sin.
 
 Admittedly, it takes some amount of faith to believe these initial assumption, but as a Christian Scientist I feel validated in my faith by the amount of healings I've been witness to, received, and seen documentary evidence of. Call it post hoc ergo propter hoc, if you'd like, but there are plenty of well-documented, medically verified healings.
 
 You mentioned that you believed my faith would result in my early death via a treatable disease, but people die every day from treatable illnesses even under medical treatment. Many people also enter hospitals with curable diseases, only to die from misdiagnosis, medical malfeasance, etc.
 
 I don't claim (nor does any Christian Scientist I know) that Christian Science treatment has been 100% effective. No reasonable person would hold medical treatment up to that standard; it seems fairly unreasonable to hold Christian Science up to it, as well.
 
 As a final note, I will not be debating Christian Science with you, but I will be happy to answer any questions you might have about my faith.

H'lo there. I am a Wiccan.
 
 The story of how I came into that faith is a bit complicated. I was raised in the Christian faith by my parents and struggled for several years with being a lesbian and hearing the condemnation in my church toward my homosexuality. I didn't tell anyone until I got out of high school, when - after years of agonizing over my natural feelings and attempting to force myself to be a heterosexual, even going out on dates and having sex with males (praying every night that God would help me change and not be "sinful") - I came out to my close friends and then to my parents.
 
 My mother was very accepting of me being a lesbian, but my father, an extremely devout right-wing christian, has never accepted me, and only recently have we even started to talk again (even now, he does not speak to the woman I have married - he refused to come to our marriage).
 
 As I entered college, I met a woman, who was a Wiccan, whom I became close friends with. She answered every question I had about Wicca, and over time led me into becoming a Wiccan when I realised that it was truly the correct faith for me. As we got to know each other, I learned that she, too was a lesbian, and our relationship deepened and whattaya know: now we've been married for 18 years and have a four year old son (Artificial Insemination).
 
 -----
 
 My personal Wiccan faith involves a belief in a creative force in the universe (it can be called "The One" or, in my preference, "The All"). I believe that all Gods and Goddesses of all religions are attempts by that particular culture to describe different aspects of The All. I believe in the God and the Goddess - male and female aspects of The All. I also worship a Celtic pantheon, each god and goddess of the pantheon a particular part or description of the God and the Goddess (which in turn are aspects of The All). I have great respect for Nature and do my best to prevent harm from coming to it.
 
 Well, that's a quick summary of what I believe as a Wiccan and how I came to be a Wiccan - if you've got any questions, just ask.

I am a Deist. My beliefs, as ancient as they may appear, are the same as many of the founders of this country. I believe in the God who created the universe without dogma. 
 
 
Deism is a religious philosophy and movement that became prominent in Great Britain, France, and the United States in the 17th and 18th centuries and continues to this day. Deism differs from theism in that according to Deism God does not interfere with human life and the laws of the universe.
 
 Deists typically reject supernatural events (prophecy, miracles) and divine revelation prominent in organized religion, along with holy books and revealed religions that assert the existence of such things. Instead, Deists hold that religious beliefs must be founded on human reason and observed features of the natural world, and that these sources reveal the existence of one God or supreme being.

 In 2003, the National Home Education Research Institute conducted a survey of 7,300 U.S. adults who had been homeschooled (5,000 for more than seven years). Their findings included:
 
 * Homeschool graduates are active and involved in their communities. 71% participate in an ongoing community service activity, like coaching a sports team, volunteering at a school, or working with a church or neighborhood association, compared with 37% of U.S. adults of similar ages from a traditional education background.
 
 * Homeschool graduates are more involved in civic affairs and vote in much higher percentages than their peers. 76% of those surveyed between the ages of 18 and 24 voted within the last five years, compared with only 29% of the corresponding U.S. populace. The numbers are even greater in older age groups, with voting levels not falling below 95%, compared with a high of 53% for the corresponding U.S. populace.
